instructions.display_text: Add the cassava purée and ½ cup water to a medium pot and use your hands to break up any lumps, then stir with a wooden spoon until smooth. Turn the heat to medium-high and cook for about 15 minutes, stirring continuously to break up any lumps that form and adding up to ½ cup more water as needed to ensure the fufu is not stiff or lumpy, until the cassava turns from bright white to off-white in color and the fufu is stretchy and smooth. Remove the pot from the heat.
Scoop 1 cup of fufu from the pot with a wooden spoon and, using wet hands to prevent sticking, roll into a ball or your desired shape. Repeat with the remaining fufu.
Serve the fufu with sawa sawa soup or the soup of your choice.
Enjoy!

components.raw_text: ½ cup water, plus more as needed
Sawa Sawa with Egusi, for serving (optional)

results.description: Cassava fufu, said to originate in West Africa, is made from fermented, puréed cassava, or yucca root, pounded with water into a soft, sticky dough.  It’s typically served with various West African soups, such as sawa sawa with egusi, groundnut soup, or okra soup. Traditionally, it is eaten by hand and swallowed, not chewed.
results.name: Cassava Fufu

instructions.display_text: To begin preparing the base of the stew, blend tomatoes and 1 habanero with 3⁄4-1 cup (180 - 240 ml) of water. Place in a bowl and set aside.
Next, blend 1 of the 2 chopped onions, garlic, and ginger with about 1⁄2 cup (120 ml) of water. Place mixture in a separate bowl and set aside.
Begin heating vegetable oil in a large pot. Add the 1 remaining chopped onion to the oil when hot, and cook for 4 minutes on medium heat.

Add the tomato and onion purees to the pot, followed by the tomato paste, shrimp bouillon, garlic powder, curry powder, thyme, white/black pepper, and Adobo. Cut the other habanero in half and add to stew. Stir mixture thoroughly and cook together for 10 minutes on low-medium heat.
Add rinsed jasmine rice and mixed veggies to the pot. Stew base should be just enough to cover the rice. Add enough water to cover the rice. Stir and add salt to taste.
Cover pot opening with a piece of foil and then the lid and cook on low-medium heat for 30-35 minutes. Cook until rice has absorbed all the liquid.
When finished, stir rice remove from stove and allow to cool.
Enjoy!

components.raw_text: 1 cup mixed vegetables of your preference (I use peas and baby carrots, chopped)

instructions.display_text: Preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C).
Make the xawaash: In a medium bowl, combine the cumin, coriander, turmeric, cardamom, black pepper, cloves, and nutmeg. Set aside.
Heat a medium oven-safe pan over medium-high heat. Add the vegetable oil, onion, tomato, garlic, and cinnamon stick. Cook until the onions have softened slightly, 5-6 minutes.
Season with salt, then add the vegetable stock cube and cilantro. Cook for 1 minute, breaking up the stock cube.
Reduce the heat to medium, then stir in the xawaash and soaked rice. Cook for about 3 minutes so rice grains lightly toast.
Pour in the hot water and increase the heat to high to bring to a boil. Cover the pot, transfer to the oven, and bake for 20 minutes. Check periodically to be sure the rice has enough water.
Remove the cooked rice from the oven and drizzle the red and orange food colorings on top. Gently mix so there are different colored grains.
Sprinkle the raisins over the hot rice, cover, and set aside.
To prepare the topping, mix the potatoes with the orange food coloring in a medium bowl (wear gloves to avoid stained fingers!).
Heat about 1 inch ( 2 cm) of oil in a large heavy-bottomed saucepan. Add the potatoes and cook for 5-6 minutes, then transfer to a baking sheet lined with paper towels to drain the excess oil.
In the same oil, fry the onion slices until browned and crispy, 2-3 minutes. Add the red peppers cooking for an additional minute. Drain on paper towels.
To assemble the rice, transfer the pilaf to a large serving platter. Top with the fried potatoes, crispy onions, and red bell peppers.
Enjoy!

results.name: Somali Bariis By Amal Dalmar

components.raw_text: 2 cups basmati rice, soaked for at least 1 hour and drained
components.extra_comment: soaked for at least 1 hour and drained

components.raw_text: 1 drop red food coloring mixed with 1 teaspoon water
3 drops orange food coloring mixed with 1 teaspoon water
1 large russet potato, cut into ¼-inch-thick matchsticks and patted dry
components.extra_comment: cut into 1/4-in (6-mm) thick matchsticks and patted dry

components.raw_text: ⅛ teaspoon orange food coloring mixed with ½ teaspoon water
2 cups long grain white rice, rinsed
4 tablespoons unsalted butter, room temperature, divided
1 pound raw medium shrimp, shell on (approximately 35 pieces/pound)
½ pound fresh mussels, shell on
2 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley leaves, plus whole parsley leaves for garnish
components.extra_comment: chopped, plus whole parsley leaves for garnish

compilations.name: Party Rice Around Africa

results.keywords: african cooking, african recipe, arros de marisco, baariis, baaris, beef, calamari, cape verde, clams, east african recipe, ghana, ghanian jollof rice, jollof rice, kenya, kenyan pilau, muscles, party food, pilau, portuguese rice, potato, rice, seafood rice, somalia, vegetarian rice, west african recipe

instructions.display_text: In an medium pot over high heat, combine the rice, bay leaves, 2 tablespoons of butter, 1 teaspoon of salt, and 4⅓ cups (1 L) of water. Bring to a boil. Cover, reduce the heat to low, and simmer for 20 minutes, or until the rice is cooked and fluffy.
Heat a large sauté pan over medium-high heat. Add a drizzle of olive oil. Toss in the peppers, onion, and garlic. Cook until the onion is slightly translucent, 8-10 minutes.
Add the red pepper flakes, remaining teaspoon of salt, the tomato paste, and remaining cup (240 ml) of water. Stir, cover, and boil for 2-3 minutes.
Add the calamari, shrimp, mussels, and peas. Stir and cover with the lid. Cook until the mussel shells open, 5-6 minutes.
Remove the pan from the heat. Add the lemon juice, remaining 2 tablespoons of butter, and chopped parsley then stir.
Transfer the cooked rice to a large bowl.
Use a slotted spoon to scoop the seafood mixture over the rice. Stir to combine, add ½ cup (120 ml) of the seafood braising liquid, and stir once more.
Garnish with parsley leaves (optional).
Enjoy!

compilations.name: Party Rice Around Africa
Perfect Dinners with Beef Stew and Rice
25 Rice Recipes
compilations.description: You can never go wrong with rice, and these easy, mouthwatering recipes prove that rice is an anytime food. Start your day with a sweet Fried Chicken Rice Burger or enjoy Pineapple Fried Rice on a special lunch date. But why settle for one when you have 25 options to try from? Let’s get cookin’!

Do you love rice but are bored of eating it in the same way? Try cooking up some Chicken Tikka Masala to go with some fragrant jasmine rice. Or make some Kenyan Beef and Potato Pilau for something more decadent. For a tasty weeknight meal, dive into a hearty bowl of Chinese Chicken Fried Rice. Always rice, ever so nice.
compilations.name: Rice Around The World

compilations.description: There's no food more versatile, multi-purpose, and comforting than rice. So you can never have too many recipes. Indulge in some Ghanaian Jollof Rice or, for something cozy on a chilly night, dive into our fried chicken and egg rice bowl. Finally, our zesty lime chicken with black beans and rice is guaranteed to please.
compilations.name: Rice Recipes For Each Day Of The Week

instructions.display_text: Add onions and 2 tablespoons of oil to a blender and pulse until smooth. Transfer to a medium bowl.
Add the diced tomatoes, tomato paste, and habanero pepper to the blender, and pulse until smooth. Transfer to a separate medium bowl.
Heat the remaining ⅓ cup (80 ml) of oil in a large, heavy-bottomed pot over medium heat.
Once the oil is shimmering, add the onion puree and cook until the water has cooked out and the puree is starting to brown, about 10 minutes.

Stir in the tomato puree and add the curry powder, garlic powder, ginger, dried herbs,  and crushed bouillon cubes. Cook for 20-30 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the stew has reduced by half and is deep red in color.

Add the rice, mixed vegetables, and water. Bring to a boil, then reduce the heat to low and cover the pot with foil and a lid. Simmer for another 30 minutes, until the rice is cooked through and the liquid is absorbed.
Enjoy!

components.raw_text: 1½ pounds flank steak, cut into strips

compilations.name: Perfect Dinners with Beef Stew and Rice
Dinner Recipes For Every Night In June

compilations.description: When you have beef on hand, you're always just minutes away from a great meal. For a hearty weeknight recipe, whip up some Nigerian beef stew paired with rice. Or, simply stir fry some beef to make chili beef noodles. If you can get your hands on high-quality beef tenderloin, pull out all the stops with this Beef Wellington recipe. Or get a taste for Vietnam with this comforting beef pho. The options are endless!
compilations.name: These Beef Recipes Are A Total Game Changer

compilations.description: From scarlet to burgundy to ruby, we have a dish for every shade of red. You’re in for a visual treat! Start your meal with a bowl of Red Wine Spaghetti followed by the hearty Nigerian Beef Stew. Try your hand at the Red Velvet Cheesecake Cupcakes for dessert. Have a red meal today!
compilations.name: Paint The Town Red!
Tasty Dinners for Every Night of December
compilations.description: End the year with a culinary big bang! 2022 is coming to an end, but your nights shouldn't without tasting these delicious recipes. We have got Baked Lobster Tails, Creamy Tuscan Chicken, Korean-Style BBQ Beef, or a 20-Minute One-Pan Pizza to cover all of your cravings. Are you convinced or should we go on?

Are you up for a hands-off, laid-back dish for a cold winter night? Well, you can’t do better than a soul-warming bowl of Eggplant Potato and Tomato Stew. Cozy up with the comforting goodness of Nigerian Beef Stew. These recipes will help you battle the cold in the most comforting way possible.
compilations.name: This Is How We Stew It!

instructions.display_text: In a food processor or blender, combine 4 chopped plum tomatoes, red bell peppers, chopped red onion, habanero peppers, garlic cloves, tomato paste, 1 tablespoon salt, 1 teaspoon pepper, and water. Puree until smooth.
Heat vegetable oil in a large pot over medium-high heat.
Add the remaining tomato, sliced onion, remaining salt, and remaining pepper. Sauté until fragrant.
Add steak, rosemary, paprika, curry powder, and bullion cubes. Cook until the steak is golden brown and cooked through, about 10 minutes.
Add the blended tomato and pepper mixture and the bay leaf.
Bring to a boil over high heat. Cover and simmer at low heat for 20 minutes, until the stew has thickened.
Fish out the bay leaf.
Remove stew from heat and let sit 10 minutes.
Serve with white rice and fried plantains. Garnish with scallions and parsley, if desired.
Enjoy!

In a bowl, add the potatoes, and fill the bowl with water until the potatoes are covered. Microwave on the potato setting for 10 minutes.  The potatoes are done when you can pierce through them with a fork. Leave in water, and set aside until ready to use.
In a large pot over medium heat, add the olive oil and 3 tablespoons of curry powder, and mix thoroughly.
Add the cubed chicken and the onions to the pot, and mix thoroughly until chicken is cooked through, about 5 minutes.
Add the peas, red bell peppers, green beans, carrots, and jalapeño pepper, and mix thoroughly.
Add the reserved potatoes, along with 6 cups (1.4 L) of the water the potatoes were cooked in to the pot, and mix thoroughly.
Add the salt, pepper, and the rest of the curry powder, and mix thoroughly.
Bring the curry to a boil, cover, and reduce heat to low. Simmer the curry for one hour on low heat. Remove from heat.
Serve with jasmine rice garnished with parsley.
Enjoy!

components.raw_text: 4 pounds boneless, skinless chicken breasts, cut into 3-inch cubes

compilations.name: Brilliant Chicken Dishes From Around The World
Curry Night Recipes!
compilations.description: Let's wake up our taste buds with some hot and fiery recipes Try our curry with a twist or stick to the classic and delicious chicken tikka masala. Whether you choose to devour this with some naan or good old rice, these curries will be the highlight of your meal! So, grab your spice box and let's get cookin'

We have hand-picked the best dinners from around the world just for you! From the flavorful Indian butter chicken to the spicy Korean bbq style pork, these recipes are as versatile as can get. So, what you waiting for? Fire up the pans and let your taste buds travel the world from the comfort of your kitchens.
compilations.name: Dinners Around The World
Keep Calm And Curry On
compilations.description: Curry is always a great option when you're looking for a wholesome, flavorful, filling dish. The Kerala-style prawn curry blends seafood with some banging coconut. The slow-cooker Thai green curry is a great meal for a busy weekday. And the Nigerian chicken curry goes great with jasmine rice. Who's hungry?

compilations.name: Chicken Dinners From Around The World

compilations.description: There's nothing a big hearty bowl of curry can't fix! Grab your favorite bread and get ready for some delicious curries. For a quick and tasty meal, check out Simple Veggie Curry! Chicken Curry Naan Bowls are the best thing you could have for dinner! Potato lovers, you must try the Easy-Peasy Potato Curry!
compilations.name: No Worries When You've Got Curries
